comments.commentBody: Agree that this smells-- do NYRB really want to become a purely Norway/Scandanavian coaching staff/system (how have they done in club and world cup comp? did i miss something?!) Odd that NYRB mgmt including Backe have praised Richie so often and extended his contract last year, but now fire him during critical period before season? Richie is known for good chemistry with players and strong views on the game - maybe these became a threat to Backe if his own player rapport is weak? (rumors from last year). Why not Backe bring in his own boys from norway or wherever...problem is they, like him, have minimal experience in this league and with such a diverse group of players. NYRB fans deserve an explanation. We need more info, but this looks B-league from here...not good sign for program.

Give humanitarian aid; stay out as Secretary Gates has advised; wait and see and let the Europeans take the lead. Ask yourselves the following questions: What can we do that is realistic financially? What can others do?

While I agree with you regarding the snobbish comments of people regarding (insert politically correct and I'm better then you comment about food or clothing here) I am going to strongly disagree with you regarding coffee. You stated above that you expect that no more then $2-4 of the $20 bag of coffee actually goes back to the farmer. For some shops this may be true, but for companies really pushing the envelope of Direct Trade that's not true.

For example if you look at the following document http://counterculturecoffee.com... this outlines all the direct trade purchases that Counter Culture Coffee made and the price they paid for them. The coffee here that they purchased for $1.85 sold for $10.85. The thing to keep in mind is that that $1.85 went directly to the farmer not the a broker who then paid the farmer less. Counter Culture then has to add shipping, roasting costs and packaging costs to that $1.85 which probably brings the cost of that bag of coffee to $6.00 or so. No where near the $16-$18 from a $20 bag.

What's the bet that he'll be back, at another major fashion-house, within a couple of years? Let's face it, it's pretty likely that someone else will snatch him up. The bottom line is MONEY. JG has been an enormous cash-cow for Dior, which was previously a moribund husk of it's former self.

This will all blow-over. The French will cease fanning themselves with scented handkerchiefs in mock indignation. Another fashion-house will employ Galliano, and in the meantime his own label will continue to prosper. Natalie Portman may never wear any of his designs again, but many other actresses with much higher profiles will continue to. The millions of Euros will continue to flood in, and the entire incident will be scene as just an unfortunate little blip in Galliano's career.

“Kwik-E-Mart owner on ‘The Simpsons’” = APU (1/16/01, 1/30/08, 2/24/08, 3/2/11): in Episode 1F10 (“Homer and Apu”), Homer succumbs to food poisoning after gorging himself on spoiled Kwik-E-Mart wares and files a lawsuit; the result is that Apu is fired by the Kwik-E-Mart Corporation, headquartered in a Himalayan convenience store where, according to a sign on the wall, “The Master knows all except combination to safe.” Apu isn’t the owner — he’s an employee; cf. “Kwik-E-Mart clerk” (9/7/08, 7/6/10), “Kwik-E-Mart clerk on ‘The Simpsons’” (11/4/01, 3/18/02, 1/2/05), “Kwik-E-Mart employee on ‘The Simpsons’” (11/30/03), “‘The Simpsons’ clerk” (9/7/09), “TV’s Kwik-E-Mart clerk” (9/30/09) = APU.

During 2008, many Kenyans repeated a national joke: that a Kikuyu (by heritage and ancestry – not by citizenship!) would be elected President in America before a Kikuyu could be elected President in Kenya. So far, the joke has proven true.

Looking at how governments change, protests that topple leaders are often led by a large, youthful, disaffected, broad middle class movements that embrace a principled idealism. This was certainly true in 1776; many of the leaders of the American Revolution were young, born into families of land owners or other means, and educated and sought to achieve a society of high ideals. This was true in China's Long March, in Ghana's use of trade union strikes in Africa in 1956, in Cuba (Fidel was first a student leader, the son of a self-made farmer); in Barack Obama's election, and now across the region in the North African-Arabian peninsula. Despite ideological differences, the formula for change often mixes differing protions of the same components. Americans dread looking at these similarities across ideologies, since often we like to sort things into good and bad, and ignore nuances and complications, while fixating on lesser threats. It is strange to hear ordinary citizens of Arab countries, speaking impeccable English, nightly reassuring and telling Americans the rise of Islamism is not something to worry about.

By ignoring the complexities of policy, or overlooking how democracy has becoming the crowning political creed of the times (as socialism once was in the mid 20th century), the administration can potentially undo many of the gains advanced by the people. Technical assistance and humanitarian aid is essential to retaining good will and a rapport with the new governments of the region. Planes with food and medical supplies should be landing now in Egypt and Tunisia. That alone would prove America's commitment to the new political landscape and send the proper signal to governments and citizens alike.

I, however, fear the “things left undone.” It would change the dynamics of world history if democracy in the region was still born, deprived of life support by the world's richest nation and greatest democracy. It would also be nice if elected officials at home would begin to appreciate the importance of listening to citizens and crafting effective compromises rather than implementing and perpetuating the rapidly abandoned politics of command and control.
--Walter Rhett
twitter.com/walterrhett

Mr. Friedman

Do you feel that Americans owe Egyptians a big apology for backing dictators and tyrants who destroyed the dreams of their own people so that people such as yourself can drive a car and only have to worry that gas prices have reached only $3 per gallon?
Or do you feel like the US government's hands are clean of the "pro-western" autocrats and torturers?

Tom Friedman somehow forgot the effect of Iraq being the only Arab democracy in the Middle East.  Of course, that would mean giving credit to Bush.  It's easier for him to give credit to Obama because of his middle name.

Those of us who get much of our news from Aljazeera know that America's best interests are not served by the Saudi's aged king. America's best interests would be served by monitoring what is happening in the world and protecting the weak and defenseless.As a younger generation starts to understand that their real enemies are the ones draping themselves in flags and swearing allegiance to countries and concepts that benefit the few, privileged and their-selves.
While us older folk thought we heard Obama talk about old ideologies of liberalism and sharing wealth the younger generation heard what Obama actually said," You are the change you have been waiting for."
In the words of Leonard Cohen "Democracy is coming to the USA."
As someone who has been transfixed by Aljazeera since the Tunisian crisis what I have seen how the older and younger generations seem to occupy two separate realities. What is happening is we are seeing a generation which has finally broken free of the insane idea that we need strong dynamic leadership to guide us through our journey.
The coverage of the recent US elections were well covered by international media and Aljazeera in particular and what was painfully obvious is that the best and brightest are not in charge. The inability of the Democrats to bring the Obama voters to the polls was not apathy but the realization that there really are very few politicians worth voting for. We need politicians who listen and can formulate solutions to our concerns not ideologues who solutions serve their-selves and their families.
When the people of Egypt banded together to protect their communities from the thugs the realization that thugaree was a function of government. Much like the wizard of OZ when the curtain is removed Gaddafi, Mubarek and Ben Ali are rather pathetic characters except for their thugs.
In a world where technology has provided us the ability to provide everyone with basic needs our governments must provide us with excuses for some to have incredible wealth as their neighbours go hungry.
I am very happy to see that the closing paragraph about Saudi Arabia because the question is not if the house of Saud will fall but when. When the house of Saud falls it will be a day of celebration in the world and hopefully the biggest celebration in Washington.
The world does not need the US to tell its people what they need it needs the strong voices of Hillary and Barack to say violence against the people is not a legitimate response to social demands.
The difference in America between a good day and a bad day is the recognition that a good day for Mexican workers is a good day for America workers or a good day for the residents of China is a good day for Americans.
Brilliant analysis! Even if it's only half true, it should give us all hope that some good might come out of those people's struggle.
How about the world wide recession. Just a coincidence?
Brilliant column. Your knowledge from the start, Beirut to Jerusalem, has been insightful.   May the powers listen.  Cheers, best, Jim

I thought the Tunisian fruit vendor was enraged about his scales being confiscated, not his cart.

At least thats how it was described in 60 minutes.

He then went to city hall to ask for them back and was rejected.

If that is so, it is poetic irony when you consider we use the symbol of the scales to represent justice.
He is a hero.
Wow, great list! Most news coverage seems to treat these uprisings as if they just sprang out of nowhere. Even just this little bit of insight helps me understand a truly pivotal moment in history.

And Mr. Friedman wants to import the same problem from overseas here.    We have the same problem as in Egypt and the Middle East, our educated youth cannot find job as in Egypt, but he prefers to import hundred of thousands H-1Bs here to make the problem much worse.  We also have a tone-deaf political class that bailed out banksters.   When are we going to have Egyptian style revolt here?

Pretty good piece: your arguments are at the least tenable.

Of course, it could all really come down to "we never really got over what were the Middle Ages in the west; perhaps it's time we stopped hating as a diversion and started figuring out how to employ our young, prepare for an eventual retirement and get enough to eat every day".

You think?
You forgot two factors--education of the masses and globalization effect.
